Ok so, here a funny ( not so funny ) story for you guys:   I was supposed to write my physics exam about accelerating and constantly moving objects on Monday. However, I broke my hand on Sunday and had an appointment on Monday, so I couldn’t go. On Tuesday I went to my Chem exam. My Physics teacher is also my chemistry teacher, so he told me “When I saw that your left hand was broken I was so happy because that meant that you’d be able to write the exams! I’d appreciate it if we were able to set an exam date for this week. So, I had two exams prepped for your class and I decided to give the others the easy exam. That means that you’ll be the only one writing the difficult exam.” 😃😃 I mean… I do want to become an astrophysicist- but yk. He told me to learn about horizontal projectiles as it was the difficult part of the exam. ACCORDINGLY, the known mathematical unification of Einstein's equations AND Maxwell's equations (given the addition of A FOURTH SPATIAL DIMENSION) is proven and explained. BALANCE AND completeness go hand in hand. it came from Xf = Xo +Vot + (1/2) a t^2..... but before you arrive with this, you should first derive equation starting from v = dx/dt where v = v_o + at.... after substituting v, you have to integrate everything (isolate dx) then you will realize where 1/2 really came from.... For vertical motion, you just have to change the variables into Yf = Yo + Voy t + (1/2) a t^2.... Note that a or a_y for vertical motion is - g or - 9.8 m/s^2

I am aware that your comment is 2 years old, but for new viewrs who might have the same question: While it is true that Vo is not zero, Voy (the vertical speed or Vo * sin) will be zero after we reach the maximum height, as the object is no longer moving up, so for the distance B to C we can use this formula (2:45) to find the height. Meaning, this case 3 is like two cases combined.

Heads up! When he's reviewing the equations you'll need for each problem at the end, let me point something out to you. In problem 2, the symmetrical trajectory problem, he says that the final speed is the same as the initial speed. He writes Si=20 then S=20. However, keep in mind that this is SPEED. More often than not, you're dealing with VELOCITY, which can be thought of as the vector version of speed. In this case, Vi = negative V. They'll have the same magnitude but OPPOSITE direction.
